Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story:
I was eating lunch on the edge of the construction site when my phone buzzed. It was a message from my younger sister: “Can we talk? I really need you.” She never asked for help unless it was serious. My mind raced with worry, but just then, the foreman walked by, reminding everyone about the optional safety training next week. “It’ll look good if you show up,” he said, glancing at me. I knew what he meant—being seen as reliable could mean more hours, maybe even a shot at team lead.

But my sister’s message weighed on me. We’d always promised to be there for each other, especially when things got tough. I could almost hear her voice, shaky and uncertain, needing her brother. At the same time, I felt the eyes of my coworkers, the silent expectation to be part of the team, to show commitment. My hands trembled as I stared at my phone, torn between the pull of family and the demands of the job, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
